questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent dry cough and shortness of breath. A CT scan of the chest reveals localized airway obstruction at the level of the terminal bronchioles. Based on Weibel's classification of the respiratory system, which generation of airways is most likely affected in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Generation 4

options.label: B
options.text: Generation 8

options.label: C
options.text: Generation 16

options.label: D
options.text: Generation 20

questions.correct_answer: C. Generation 16

questions.text: Which of the following statements about intra-alveolar pressure changes during normal breathing is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The maximum and minimum intra-alveolar pressure is at start of expiration and start of inspiration respectively

options.label: B
options.text: Minimum Intra-alveolar pressure is approximately -1 mm Hg during inspiration.

options.label: C
options.text: Maximum Intra-alveolar pressure is approximately +1 mm Hg during expiration.

options.label: D
options.text: At the end of both inspiration and expiration, intra-alveolar pressure is 0 mm Hg.

questions.correct_answer: A. The maximum and minimum intra-alveolar pressure is at start of expiration and start of inspiration respectively
questions.explanation:
Phase of Respiration

Intra-Alveolar Pressure (IAP)

Resting Condition

0 mm Hg

Start of Inspiration

0 mm Hg

Middle of Inspiration

-1 mm Hg

End of Inspiration

0 mm Hg

Start of Expiration

0 mm Hg

Middle of Expiration

+1 mm Hg

End of Expiration

0 mm Hg

questions.text: Uptake of various substances during their transit through a pulmonary capillary is shown here. Curve B represents:

options.label: A
options.text: N2O

options.label: B
options.text: O2

options.label: C
options.text: CO2

options.label: D
options.text: CO

questions.correct_answer: B. O2

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with a history of asthma presents with complaints of shortness of breath and wheezing. Pulmonary function tests are performed and indicate that the patient's dynamic compliance is significantly reducd, while static compliance remains relatively unchanged. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Surfactant deficiency leading to increased alveolar surface tension

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced chest wall compliance due to muscle weakness

options.label: C
options.text: Increased airway resistance due to bronchospasm

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of fibrotic tissue in the lungs, restricting lung expansion

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased airway resistance due to bronchospasm

questions.text: Which of the following correctly depicts A ?

options.label: A
options.text: Emphysema

options.label: B
options.text: Lung fibrosis

options.label: C
options.text: Myasthenia Gravis

options.label: D
options.text: Kyphoscoliosis

questions.correct_answer: A. Emphysema

questions.text: Which of the following denotes the compliance curve depicting both inspiratory and expiratory phase? (Y-axis denotes volume and x-axis denotes pressure)

options.label: A
options.text: No text content

questions.correct_answer: Unknown

questions.text: In the alveoli, surfactant primarily reduces surface tension by:

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the viscosity of the alveolar fluid, thereby reducing the tendency to collapse

options.label: B
options.text: Interfering with the diffusion of water molecules across the alveolar lining.

options.label: C
options.text: Spreading phospholipids and proteins uniformly across the alveolar surface.

options.label: D
options.text: Forming a film that alters the behavior of water molecules at the air-liquid interface

questions.correct_answer: D. Forming a film that alters the behavior of water molecules at the air-liquid interface

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Old-age lung has high compliance

options.label: B
options.text: Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension oppose each other during expansion of alveoli

options.label: C
options.text: Hyaline membrane disease has low compliance and high surface tension

options.label: D
options.text: Low compliance of the lungs is seen in Atelectasis

questions.correct_answer: B. Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension oppose each other during expansion of alveoli

questions.text: A patient's lung volume increases by 500 ml when their transpulmonary pressure increases from 3 cm H2O to 5.5 cm H2O. What is the compliance of the patient's lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: 100 ml/cm

options.label: B
options.text: 150 ml/cm

options.label: C
options.text: 200 ml/cm

options.label: D
options.text: 250 ml/cm

questions.correct_answer: C. 200 ml/cm

questions.text: Match the following zones of the lungs with their corresponding pressure relationships and blood flow characteristics. Zone Pressure Relationship Blood Flow Characteristic 1 A) Pulmonary artery pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure > Alveolar pressure i) Continuous blood flow 2 B) Alveolar pressure > Pulmonary artery pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure ii) No blood flow 3 C) Pulmonary artery pressure > Alveolar pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure iii) Intermittent blood flow (only during systole)

options.label: A
options.text: 1 - A - i, 2 - B - ii, 3 - C - iii

options.label: B
options.text: 1 - B - ii, 2 - C - iii, 3 - A - i

options.label: C
options.text: 1 - C - iii, 2 - B - ii, 3 - A - i

options.label: D
options.text: 1 - B - ii, 2 - A - i, 3 - C - iii

questions.correct_answer: B. 1 - B - ii, 2 - C - iii, 3 - A - i
questions.explanation:
Zone

Pressure Relationship

Blood Flow Characteristic

1

Alveolar pressure > Pulmonary artery pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure

No blood flow, as alveolar pressure occludes the capillaries.

2

Pulmonary artery pressure > Alveolar pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure

Intermittent blood flow occurs during systole.

3

Pulmonary artery pressure > Pulmonary venous pressure > Alveolar pressure

Continuous blood flow.

questions.text: Two separate patients are being considered for respiratory distress. Imaging reveals an obstruction in the right bronchus in one patient and an embolism in the pulmonary arteriole in another patient. Based on these findings, what are the expected changes in the ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratio and the partial pressures of oxygen (PO2) and carbon dioxide (PCO2) in the affected alveoli?

options.label: A
options.text: In the obstructed bronchus, the V/Q ratio is infinite, and the partial pressures are PO2​​ = 149 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 0.3 mm Hg.

options.label: B
options.text: In the embolized vessel, the V/Q ratio is zero, and the partial pressures are PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 46 mm Hg.

options.label: C
options.text: In the obstructed bronchus, the V/Q ratio is zero, and the partial pressures are PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2 = 46 mm Hg.

options.label: D
options.text: In the embolized vessel, the V/Q ratio is infinite, and the partial pressures are PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2​​ = 46 mm Hg.

questions.correct_answer: C. In the obstructed bronchus, the V/Q ratio is zero, and the partial pressures are PO2​​ = 40 mmHg and PCO2 = 46 mm Hg.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of shortness of breath on exertion presents to the OPD. During the examination, it is noted that his ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratio varies significantly in different regions of the lungs. What are the expected partial pressures of oxygen (pO2) and carbon dioxide (pCO2​​) at the apex, middle, and base of the lungs in the upright position?

options.label: A
options.text: At the apex: pO2 is lowest and pCO2​​ is highest.

options.label: B
options.text: At the base: pO2​​ is highest and pCO2 is lowest.

options.label: C
options.text: At the middle: pO2​​ is highest and pCO2​​ is lowest.

options.label: D
options.text: At the base: pO2​​ is lowest and pCO2 is highest.

questions.correct_answer: D. At the base: pO2​​ is lowest and pCO2 is highest.
questions.explanation:
Region of Lungs

V/Q Ratio

PO2 (mm Hg)

PCO2 (mm Hg)

pH of blood

Apex

Highest (3.3)

Highest (132)

Lowest (28)

7.51 (slightly alkaline)

Middle

Moderate (0.8)

100-104

40

7.4

Base

Lowest (0.6)

Lowest (89)

Highest (42)

7.39 (slightly acidic)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient is evaluated for differences in ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratios in various positions. In the upright position, the V/Q ratios at the apex, middle, and base of the lungs differ due to gravitational effects. Which of the following statements correctly describes the V/Q ratio at these lung regions in the upright vs. supine position?

options.label: A
options.text: In the upright position, the V/Q ratio is highest at the base of the lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: In the upright position, the V/Q ratio is highest at the apex of the lungs.

options.label: C
options.text: In the supine position, the V/Q ratio difference between the apex and base is more pronounced than in the upright position.

options.label: D
options.text: In the supine position, the V/Q ratio is highest at the middle of the lungs.

questions.correct_answer: B. In the upright position, the V/Q ratio is highest at the apex of the lungs.
questions.explanation:
Position

Region

V/Q 

Ratio

Explanation

  Upright

Apex

3.3 

    (highest)

Perfusion decreases drastically at the apex, making the V/Q ratio highest despite lower ventilation.
 

Middle

0.8 

Both ventilation and perfusion are moderate, resulting in a balanced V/Q ratio.
 

Base

0.6 

(lowest)

Perfusion is highest at the base, causing the V/Q ratio to be lowest despite higher ventilation.

  Supine

All 

regions

    Relatively uniform

In the supine position, gravitational effects are minimized, leading to 

a more uniform V/Q ratio.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with shortness of breath and fatigue. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his tidal volume is 400 mL. The dead space is estimated to be 150 mL. Which of the following statements about ventilation and perfusion is/are correct? 1) Pulmonary ventilation refers to the amount of air entering the lungs in a minute, while alveolar ventilation is the volume of air reaching the alveolar zone for gas exchange. 2) Pulmonary ventilation for this patient is approximately 6.4L/min. 3) Alveolar ventilation for this patient is approximately 4L/min. 4) Perfusion is the blood flow at the level of the alveoli which is approximately equal to cardiac output from the right ventricle.

options.label: A
options.text: 1 and 4

options.label: B
options.text: 1, 2 and 4

options.label: D
options.text: 1, 3 and 4

questions.explanation:
Statement

Description

Explanation

1) Pulmonary ventilation refers to the amount of air entering the lungs in a minute, while alveolar ventilation is the volume of air reaching the alveolar zone for gas exchange.

Correct

Pulmonary ventilation = TV x RR;

Alveolar ventilation = (TV - Dead Space) x RR.

2) Pulmonary ventilation for this patient is approximately 6.4 L/min.

Correct

Pulmonary ventilation = 400 mL x 16 = 6.4 L/min.

3) Alveolar ventilation for this patient is approximately 4 L/min.

Correct

Alveolar ventilation = (400 mL - 150 mL) x 16 = 4.0 L/min.

4) Perfusion is the blood flow at the level of the alveoli which is approximately equal to cardiac output from the right ventricle.

Correct

Perfusion is typically equal to the cardiac output of the right ventricle, approximately 5.4 L/min.

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes normal inspiration?

options.label: A
options.text: Diaphragm relaxation leads to decreased intrapleural pressure, allowing air to enter the lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: Diaphragm contraction creates negative intrapleural pressure, causing air to enter the lungs.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased intra-alveolar pressure from diaphragm contraction draws air into the lungs.

options.label: D
options.text: External intercostal muscle relaxation decreases intrapleural pressure, expanding the alveoli.

questions.correct_answer: B. Diaphragm contraction creates negative intrapleural pressure, causing air to enter the lungs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with severe shortness of breath and chest pain after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. On examination, he is tachycardic and hypotensive, with decreased breath sounds on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left. Which of the following pressure changes most accurately explains the underlying mechanism of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased intrapulmonary pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Increased intrapleural pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased intrapleural pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased intrapulmonary pressure

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased intrapleural pressure

questions.text: A 35-year-old male holds his breath at the end of normal expiration. Which of the following accurately describes the condition of his lungs at this moment?

options.label: A
options.text: The alveolar pressure is higher than the atmospheric pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: The intrapleural pressure is higher than the atmospheric pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: The functional residual capacity is at its minimum.

options.label: D
options.text: The elastic recoil forces of the lungs and chest wall are in equilibrium.

questions.correct_answer: D. The elastic recoil forces of the lungs and chest wall are in equilibrium.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of asthma presents to the emergency department with severe dyspnea. On examination, she is using accessory muscles to breathe and her oxygen saturation is reduced. Arterial blood gas analysis shows a high level of carbon dioxide (PaCO₂) despite increased ventilation. A bedside pulmonary function test reveals that her physiological dead space has increased compared to her last visit. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the increase in physiological dead space in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased alveolar dead space due to poorly ventilated but well-perfused alveoli, leading to reduced effective gas exchange.

options.label: B
options.text: Anatomical dead space has increased due to an obstruction in the conducting airways, causing less air to reach the alveoli.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased alveolar dead space due to poorly perfused but well-ventilated alveoli, reducing the amount of air available for gas exchange.

options.label: D
options.text: A reduction in anatomical dead space due to inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to a decrease in overall physiological dead space

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased alveolar dead space due to poorly perfused but well-ventilated alveoli, reducing the amount of air available for gas exchange.

questions.text: In the Nitrogen Washout Method for measuring lung volumes, what does the phase III observed in the graph represent?

options.label: A
options.text: The volume of air in the conducting zone.

options.label: B
options.text: The mixed air from the conducting zone and alveoli.

options.label: C
options.text: The pure alveolar air coming from the alveolar region.

options.label: D
options.text: The closing volume of the lungs.

questions.correct_answer: C. The pure alveolar air coming from the alveolar region.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes elective surgery under general anesthesia. During the procedure, her respiratory parameters are closely monitored. Which of the following statements best explains how general anesthesia typically affects anatomical dead space?

options.label: A
options.text: General anesthesia increases alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space.

options.label: B
options.text: General anesthesia decreases anatomical dead space by promoting bronchoconstriction.

options.label: C
options.text: General anesthesia does not affect anatomical dead space but increases alveolar dead space.

options.label: D
options.text: General anesthesia increases anatomical dead space due to the loss of bronchial tone, leading to bronchial dilation.

questions.correct_answer: D. General anesthesia increases anatomical dead space due to the loss of bronchial tone, leading to bronchial dilation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of smoking presents with a persistent cough and occasional wheezing. During a physical examination, you notice that the patient has increased breath sounds over the central airways. In which part of the respiratory system is the velocity of airflow is high, leading to turbulent airflow in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Alveoli

options.label: B
options.text: Trachea

options.label: C
options.text: Terminal bronchioles

options.label: D
options.text: Respiratory bronchioles

questions.correct_answer: B. Trachea

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of chronic bronchitis presents with increased difficulty in breathing. Based on Poiseuille's law and the distribution of airway resistance, which part of the respiratory system contributes the most to the total resistance to airflow?

options.label: A
options.text: Alveolar ducts

options.label: B
options.text: Small airways (bronchioles)

options.label: C
options.text: Medium to large-size bronchi (lobar and segmental bronchi)

options.label: D
options.text: Upper airways (pharynx and larynx)

questions.correct_answer: C. Medium to large-size bronchi (lobar and segmental bronchi)

questions.text: A premature infant presents with severe respiratory distress shortly after birth. The neonate is diagnosed with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). Which type of alveolar cell is most likely deficient in this condition, leading to inadequate surfactant production?

options.label: A
options.text: Type I pneumocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Type II pneumocytes

options.label: C
options.text: Alveolar macrophages

options.label: D
options.text: Endothelial cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Type II pneumocytes

questions.text: All of the following statements about Clara cells of the respiratory tract are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: They are found in the bronchioles.

options.label: B
options.text: They stabilise surfactant proteins

options.label: C
options.text: They have cilia.

options.label: D
options.text: They detoxify harmful substances.

questions.correct_answer: C. They have cilia.

questions.text: A biopsy from a segment of the respiratory tree reveals pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. From which part of the respiratory tract was this sample most likely taken?

options.label: A
options.text: Alveoli

options.label: B
options.text: Terminal bronchioles

options.label: C
options.text: Trachea

options.label: D
options.text: Respiratory bronchioles

questions.correct_answer: C. Trachea
